content.definition: Abnormal motor posturing refers to involuntary, reflexive flexion or extension of the limbs in comatose patients, indicating severe brain injury and serving as a clinical marker for the level of brainstem damage (above or below the red nucleus).
content.atAGlance:
• Decorticate (Flexor): Arms flexed/adducted (hands like 'C's moving toward the 'Cord'), legs extended. Indicates lesion above the [[red_nucleus]] (e.g., cerebral hemispheres, internal capsule).
  • Decerebrate (Extensor): Arms extended/pronated, legs extended. Indicates lesion at or below the [[red_nucleus]] (e.g., midbrain, upper pons).
  • Prognosis: Decerebrate posturing generally indicates more severe brainstem damage and a worse prognosis than decorticate.
  • Pathophysiology: Disinhibition of the [[rubrospinal_tract]] (flexion) vs. dominance of the [[vestibulospinal_tract]] (extension).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember: Decorticate = Hands near the Cor (Heart).
content.takeAway: Abnormal motor posturing distinguishes the level of brain injury: Decorticate (flexor) implies hemispheric damage sparing the red nucleus, while Decerebrate (extensor) implies deeper brainstem damage affecting the red nucleus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brain Injury] --> B{Lesion Location?}; B -->|Above Red Nucleus| C[Decorticate Posturing]; B -->|At/Below Red Nucleus| D[Decerebrate Posturing]; C --> E[Flexor Tone Dominates]; D --> F[Extensor Tone Dominates];

content.definition: Absence seizures (formerly petit mal) are a type of generalized seizure primarily affecting children, characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness ("staring spells") without loss of postural tone or postictal confusion, associated with a distinct 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG pattern.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Sudden behavioral arrest (staring), eyelid fluttering, or automatisms (lip smacking); lasts ~10 seconds; immediate return to baseline (no postictal state).
  • Triggers: Often provoked by hyperventilation.
  • EEG: Classic generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges.
  • Treatment: First-line is [[ethosuximide]] (blocks T-type Ca2+ channels); [[valproate]] is second-line (especially if co-occurring tonic-clonic seizures).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[focal_impaired_awareness_seizure]] (complex partial) which does have a postictal state and lasts longer.
content.takeAway: Absence seizures are pediatric generalized seizures defined by brief staring spells and a pathognomonic 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG, uniquely treated with [[ethosuximide]].
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Thalamocortical Circuitry] --> B[Abnormal Oscillation]; B --> C[3 Hz Spike-and-Wave]; C --> D[Brief Loss of Awareness]; D --> E[No Postictal Confusion];

content.definition: Ethosuximide is a narrow-spectrum anticonvulsant that acts by blocking T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, specifically indicated for the treatment of [[absence_seizure]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated T-type Ca2+ channels in the [[thalamus]], disrupting the thalamocortical oscillations responsible for absence seizures.
  • Clinical Use: First-line monotherapy for [[absence_seizure]].
  • Adverse Effects: GI distress (nausea/vomiting), fatigue, headache, itching, and rarely [[stevens_johnson_syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember "Ethosuximide for Everyone's Favorite Generalized Heart-throb" (EFGH: Ethosuximide, Fatigue, GI distress, Headache). Or simply: It SUCKS (Ethosuximide) to have Silent Seizures.
content.takeAway: Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for [[absence_seizure]] because it specifically targets the T-type calcium channels in the thalamus that generate the characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave rhythm.

content.definition: Acalculia is an acquired neurological deficit characterized by the inability to perform simple mathematical calculations, classically associated with lesions to the dominant parietal lobe (specifically the angular gyrus).
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dominant (usually Left) [[parietal_lobe]] (Angular Gyrus).
  • Associations: A core component of [[gerstmann_syndrome]] (along with agraphia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation).
  • Etiology: Stroke (e.g., [[middle_cerebral_artery]] infarct), tumor, or neurodegeneration.
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient cannot subtract 7 from 100 serially and has right-left confusion, suspect a dominant parietal lesion.
content.takeAway: Acalculia is a localizing sign for dominant parietal lobe dysfunction, most famously as part of the tetrad of [[gerstmann_syndrome]].

content.definition: The Accessory Nerve (CN XI) is a purely motor cranial nerve that originates from the upper cervical spinal cord, enters the skull via the foramen magnum, and exits via the [[jugular_foramen]] to innervate the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and trapezius muscles.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Head turning (SCM) and shoulder shrugging (Trapezius).
  • Course: Spinal roots C1-C5 → Foramen Magnum → Jugular Foramen → Muscles.
  • Lesion Findings:
    - LMN Lesion: Ipsilateral shoulder droop (weak trapezius), difficulty turning head to the contralateral side (weak ipsilateral SCM).
    - Winged Scapula: Can occur (lateral winging) but distinct from Long Thoracic Nerve injury (medial winging).
  • USMLE Tip: To test the Right SCM, the patient turns their head to the Left. A Right CN XI lesion causes weakness turning head to the Left.
content.takeAway: CN XI is unique for its spinal origin and cranial exit; damage results in ipsilateral shoulder weakness and difficulty turning the head away from the lesion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[C1-C5 Spinal Roots] --> B[Foramen Magnum]; B --> C[Jugular Foramen]; C --> D[Sternocleidomastoid]; C --> E[Trapezius];

content.definition: The Accommodation Reflex is the visual response to focusing on a near object, characterized by the triad of convergence, miosis (pupillary constriction), and lens thickening (accommodation), mediated by the parasympathetic fibers of [[oculomotor_nerve]].
content.atAGlance:
• Triad:
    1. Convergence: Medial recti contraction (CN III).
    2. Miosis: Sphincter pupillae contraction (CN III parasympathetics) to increase depth of field.
    3. Accommodation: Ciliary muscle contraction → Zonules relax → Lens rounds up (increases refractive power).
  • Pathway: Retina → Optic Nerve → LGN → Visual Cortex → Superior Colliculus/Pretectum → Edinger-Westphal Nucleus → Ciliary Ganglion → Eye.
  • Clinical Relevance: Argyll Robertson Pupil (Neurosyphilis) shows "Light-Near Dissociation" (pupils accommodate but do not react to light).
  • USMLE Tip: Ciliary muscle contraction leads to zonule relaxation. This is counterintuitive but critical.
content.takeAway: Accommodation allows for near vision through a coordinated parasympathetic response that rounds the lens, constricts the pupil, and converges the eyes; this reflex can be spared in pathways affecting the light reflex (Light-Near Dissociation).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Visual Cortex] --> B[Edinger-Westphal Nucleus]; B -->|CN III Parasympathetic| C[Ciliary Ganglion]; C --> D[Sphincter Pupillae (Miosis)]; C --> E[Ciliary Muscle (Lens Rounding)];

content.definition: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts primarily in the proximal convoluted tubule of the kidney to inhibit HCO3- reabsorption, causing a metabolic acidosis and diuresis, while also reducing aqueous humor and CSF production.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Inhibits carbonic anhydrase → Decreased H+ secretion → Increased Na+/K+/HCO3- excretion.
  • Clinical Uses: [[glaucoma]] (decreases aqueous humor), [[idiopathic_intracranial_hypertension]] (decreases CSF), [[altitude_sickness]] (metabolic acidosis stimulates respiration), metabolic alkalosis.
  • Adverse Effects: Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 2), paresthesias, NH3 toxicity, sulfa allergy, hypokalemia, kidney stones (calcium phosphate).
  • USMLE Tip: "ACID-azolamide" causes Acidosis. Useful for alkalinizing urine (e.g., to excrete uric acid/cystine) but contraindicated in cirrhosis (traps ammonia).
content.takeAway: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that uniquely causes metabolic acidosis by dumping bicarbonate, making it useful for altitude sickness and glaucoma, but risking Type 2 RTA.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Acetazolamide] --|Inhibits| B[Carbonic Anhydrase]; B --> C[Decreased H+ Formation]; C --> D[Decreased Na+/H+ Exchange]; D --> E[Increased HCO3- Excretion]; E --> F[Metabolic Acidosis];

content.definition: Acetylcholine (ACh) is a major neurotransmitter synthesized from choline and acetyl-CoA that acts on nicotinic (ligand-gated ion channels) and muscarinic (G-protein coupled) receptors to mediate motor control, autonomic functions, and cognition.
content.atAGlance:
• Sites of Action:
    1. NMJ: Somatic motor neurons (Nicotinic).
    2. Autonomic Ganglia: Both Sympathetic and Parasympathetic (Nicotinic).
    3. Parasympathetic Effectors: Smooth muscle, glands, heart (Muscarinic).
    4. CNS: Basal nucleus of Meynert (Cognition/Memory).
  • Synthesis/Degradation: Made by Choline Acetyltransferase (ChAT); degraded by [[acetylcholinesterase]] (AChE).
  • Pathology: Decreased in [[alzheimer_disease]] and [[huntington_disease]]; Increased in [[parkinson_disease]] (relative to dopamine).
  • USMLE Tip: In the Sympathetic NS, ACh is the neurotransmitter at the ganglion AND at the Sweat Glands (muscarinic) and Adrenal Medulla (nicotinic).
content.takeAway: Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter of the parasympathetic nervous system and the neuromuscular junction; its levels are critically reduced in [[alzheimer_disease]] and targeted by AChE inhibitors.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choline + Acetyl-CoA] -->|ChAT| B[Acetylcholine]; B -->|Release| C[Synaptic Cleft]; C -->|AChE| D[Choline + Acetate]; C --> E[Nicotinic/Muscarinic Receptors];

content.definition: The Achilles Reflex (Ankle Jerk) is a deep tendon reflex mediated by the S1 and S2 nerve roots (primarily S1), where striking the Achilles tendon causes plantar flexion of the foot.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: S1, S2.
  • Nerve: [[tibial_nerve]].
  • Action: Plantar flexion of the foot via the gastrocnemius/soleus muscles.
  • Clinical Significance:
    - Decreased/Absent: S1 radiculopathy (e.g., herniated disc), peripheral neuropathy (e.g., diabetes), [[guillain_barre_syndrome]].
    - Delayed Relaxation: Classic sign of [[hypothyroidism]].
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: "S1, S2, buckle my shoe" (Achilles reflex).
content.takeAway: The Achilles Reflex primarily tests the integrity of the S1 nerve root and the tibial nerve; loss suggests pathology at this level or peripheral neuropathy.

content.definition: An Action Potential is a rapid, transient, and regenerative change in membrane potential that propagates along an excitable membrane (neuron or muscle), driven by the sequential opening and closing of voltage-gated sodium and potassium channels.
content.atAGlance:
• Phases:
    0. Depolarization: Voltage-gated Na+ channels open (Na+ influx).
    1. Repolarization: Na+ channels inactivate, Voltage-gated K+ channels open (K+ efflux).
    2. Hyperpolarization: K+ channels remain open, membrane potential dips below resting.
  • Threshold: All-or-none principle (usually -55 mV).
  • Refractory Periods:
    - Absolute: Na+ channels inactivated (no new AP possible).
    - Relative: Na+ channels reset but K+ efflux continues (requires stronger stimulus).
  • USMLE Tip: [[tetrodotoxin]] (Pufferfish) blocks Na+ channels (prevents depolarization). [[tetraethylammonium]] blocks K+ channels (prolongs repolarization).
content.takeAway: The Action Potential is the fundamental unit of neural communication, driven by Na+ influx (depolarization) followed by K+ efflux (repolarization), a sequence targeted by numerous toxins and anesthetics.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Resting Potential] -->|Stimulus| B[Threshold Reached]; B -->|Na+ Channels Open| C[Depolarization]; C -->|Na+ Inactivate / K+ Open| D[Repolarization]; D -->|K+ Slow Close| E[Hyperpolarization]; E -->|Na+/K+ Pump| A;

content.definition: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an acute, monophasic inflammatory demyelinating disorder of the CNS that typically occurs following a viral infection or vaccination, characterized by multifocal neurologic deficits and altered mental status.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry leads to autoimmune demyelination.
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapid onset of multifocal deficits (e.g., ataxia, weakness, vision loss) + Encephalopathy (confusion/coma) occurring 1-2 weeks post-infection (e.g., Measles, VZV) or vaccination.
  • Imaging: MRI shows multiple, asymmetric, hyperintense white matter lesions.
  • Differentiation: Unlike [[multiple_sclerosis]], ADEM is typically monophasic (one-time event) and involves encephalopathy.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a child with neurologic symptoms weeks after a viral illness or vaccine (e.g., Rabies vaccine).
content.takeAway: ADEM is a post-infectious autoimmune attack on CNS myelin, distinguished from MS by its monophasic course and the presence of altered mental status (encephalopathy).

content.definition: Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common subtype of [[guillain_barre_syndrome]], characterized by an acute, ascending, symmetrical autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves and roots, often triggered by a preceding infection.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry (e.g., anti-ganglioside antibodies) following infection (classically [[campylobacter_jejuni]], Zika, CMV) leads to immune attack on Schwann cells/myelin.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symmetric ascending muscle weakness/paralysis, absent deep tendon reflexes (areflexia), and potential autonomic dysregulation or respiratory failure.
  • Diagnosis: CSF shows albuminocytologic dissociation (high protein, normal WBC). Nerve conduction studies show slowed conduction (demyelination).
  • Treatment: IVIG or Plasmapheresis. Steroids are NOT effective.
  • USMLE Tip: "Ascending paralysis" after bloody diarrhea ([[campylobacter_jejuni]]) is the classic vignette. Watch for respiratory failure (measure Vital Capacity).
content.takeAway: AIDP is the classic form of Guillain-Barr√©, presenting as an ascending paralysis with areflexia and albuminocytologic dissociation, requiring urgent monitoring for respiratory compromise.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Infection e.g. Campylobacter] --> B[Antibody Production]; B --> C[Cross-reactivity with Gangliosides]; C --> D[Attack on Schwann Cells]; D --> E[Peripheral Demyelination]; E --> F[Ascending Paralysis];

content.definition: The Adenohypophysis is the glandular anterior lobe of the [[pituitary_gland]], derived from oral ectoderm ([[rathke_pouch]]), which synthesizes and secretes six major hormones in response to hypothalamic releasing factors delivered via the hypophyseal portal system.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryology: Derived from Rathke's Pouch (surface ectoderm), unlike the neurohypophysis (neuroectoderm).
  • Hormones (FLAT PiG): FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH (Basophils); Prolactin, GH (Acidophils).
  • Regulation: Controlled by the [[hypothalamus]] via the hypophyseal portal system (blood), not direct neural connection.
  • Pathology: [[pituitary_adenoma]] (e.g., Prolactinoma), [[sheehan_syndrome]] (ischemic necrosis post-partum), [[craniopharyngioma]] (Rathke's pouch remnant).
  • USMLE Tip: Acidophils (GH, Prolactin) stain pink; Basophils (FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH) stain blue. "B-FLAT".
content.takeAway: The Adenohypophysis is the master glandular center derived from oral ectoderm, regulating growth, metabolism, and reproduction through the secretion of tropic hormones under hypothalamic vascular control.

content.definition: Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded linear DNA virus responsible for a wide range of clinical syndromes, most notably pharyngoconjunctival fever, pneumonia, and hemorrhagic cystitis.
content.atAGlance:
• Transmission: Respiratory droplets, fecal-oral, direct contact (fomites). Highly stable in the environment.
  • Clinical Syndromes:
    - Pharyngoconjunctival Fever: Fever + Sore throat + [[conjunctivitis]] ("Pink eye").
    - Pneumonia: Especially in military recruits (vaccine available for military).
    - Hemorrhagic Cystitis: Hematuria and dysuria in children.
    - Gastroenteritis: Watery diarrhea.
  • Histology: Intranuclear inclusions.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a child with "Pink eye" after swimming (swimming pool conjunctivitis) or a military recruit with pneumonia.
content.takeAway: Adenovirus is a hardy DNA virus that causes outbreaks of conjunctivitis, respiratory illness (military recruits), and hemorrhagic cystitis in children.

content.definition: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive peroxisomal disorder caused by a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, leading to impaired beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), which accumulate in and damage the adrenal glands and CNS myelin.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Defective transport of VLCFAs into peroxisomes → Accumulation of VLCFAs → Toxicity to adrenal cortex and white matter.
  • Clinical Presentation: Progressive neurologic deterioration (dementia, vision loss, ataxia) + [[adrenal_insufficiency]] (skin hyperpigmentation, hypotension) in young boys.
  • Genetics: X-linked recessive.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated VLCFAs in plasma.
  • USMLE Tip: Think of this when a young boy presents with behavioral changes/school failure AND signs of Addison disease (tan skin, low Na, high K).
content.takeAway: Adrenoleukodystrophy is a peroxisomal disease of VLCFA accumulation that uniquely combines progressive CNS demyelination with primary adrenal insufficiency.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[ABCD1 Mutation] --> B[Impaired Peroxisomal Entry]; B --> C[Accumulation of VLCFAs]; C --> D[Adrenal Gland Damage]; C --> E[CNS Demyelination]; D --> F[Adrenal Insufficiency]; E --> G[Neurologic Deterioration];

content.definition: Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of irreversible central vision loss in the elderly, characterized by the degeneration of the macula due to oxidative stress and the accumulation of extracellular deposits called drusen.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - Dry (Non-exudative): Gradual vision loss; characterized by subretinal drusen (yellow deposits) and pigmentary changes. Most common (85%).
    - Wet (Exudative): Rapid vision loss; characterized by choroidal neovascularization (VEGF-driven) leading to bleeding/leakage.
  • Clinical: Central scotoma (loss of central vision), metamorphopsia (distortion of straight lines).
  • Treatment:
    - Dry: Antioxidant vitamins (AREDS), smoking cessation.
    - Wet: Anti-VEGF injections (e.g., [[ranibizumab]], [[bevacizumab]]).
  • USMLE Tip: "Metamorphopsia" (wavy lines on Amsler grid) suggests Wet AMD. Peripheral vision is preserved (unlike [[glaucoma]]).
content.takeAway: AMD destroys central vision (macula) while sparing peripheral vision; Dry AMD involves drusen, while Wet AMD involves neovascularization treatable with anti-VEGF therapy.

content.definition: Agraphia is an acquired neurological deficit characterized by the inability to write or communicate through writing, often resulting from lesions in the dominant parietal lobe or frontal lobe language centers.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dominant [[parietal_lobe]] (Angular Gyrus) or Frontal Lobe (Exner's area).
  • Associations: A core component of [[gerstmann_syndrome]] (Agraphia + Acalculia + Finger Agnosia + Left-Right Disorientation).
  • Context: Can occur in isolation or with aphasia (e.g., [[broca_aphasia]] patients have agraphia matching their speech deficits).
  • USMLE Tip: Agraphia without aphasia points strongly to the dominant angular gyrus (Gerstmann Syndrome).
content.takeAway: Agraphia is the loss of writing ability, serving as a key localizing sign for dominant parietal lobe pathology, particularly when grouped with the other elements of [[gerstmann_syndrome]].

content.definition: Akathisia is an extrapyramidal symptom characterized by a subjective feeling of inner restlessness and an objective inability to sit still (e.g., pacing, tapping feet), most commonly caused by [[antipsychotics]] blocking dopamine receptors.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: High-potency typical [[antipsychotics]] (e.g., [[haloperidol]]) or antiemetics (e.g., [[metoclopramide]]).
  • Timeline: Days to weeks after starting medication.
  • Differentiation: Often mistaken for worsening agitation/psychosis (leading to increased drug dose, worsening the akathisia).
  • Treatment: Decrease dose, switch to atypical, or treat with Beta-blockers ([[propranolol]]) or Benzodiazepines. Benztropine is less effective here than for dystonia.
  • USMLE Tip: Patient on Haloperidol feels "jumping out of their skin" and keeps pacing the room. Treat with Propranolol.
content.takeAway: Akathisia is a drug-induced motor restlessness often misdiagnosed as anxiety; unlike other EPS, it responds best to beta-blockers ([[propranolol]]) rather than anticholinergics.
